review.title: A Complete framework for ambush avoidance in realistic environments
review.abstract: Operating vehicles in adversarial environments between a recurring origin-destination pair requires new planning techniques. A two players zero-sum game is introduced. The goal of the first player is to minimize the expected casualties undergone by a convoy. The goal of the second player is to maximize this damage. The outcome of the game is obtained via a linear program that solves the corresponding minmax optimization problem over this outcome. Different environment models are defined in order to compute routing strategies over unstructured environments. To compare these methods for increasingly accurate representations of the environment, a grid-based model is chosen to represent the environment and the existence of a sufficient network size is highlighted. A global framework for the generation of realistic routing strategies between any two points is described. This framework requires a good assessment of the potential casualties at any location, therefore the most important parameters are identified. Finally the framework is tested on real world environments.

sections.heading: A. Game Description
sections.text: The problem of interest is to plan a path for a convoy that leads from Origin A to Destination B, where enemy forces might try to ambush him. It is modeled as two players pursuing a non-cooperative zero-sum game, meaning that a player's only goal is to optimize his personal gain (not cooperatively) and the sum of the score across all players is zero. Player 1, BLUE, chooses a path from Origin to Destination. Player 2, RED, chooses a number of locations where he wants to ambush, while the number of ambushes depends on BLUE's resources. In the rest of this paper, RED has only one resource, i.e. it can only ambush because we are interested in mixed strategies. It makes the sum of probabilities over all possible states equal to a higher integer for RED. If BLUE's path leads through an ambush, then RED wins.

sections.heading: III. FRAMEWORK FOR UNSTRUCTURED ENVIRONMENTS
sections.text: Although the approach described in Section II was partially addressed in [8, 2], previous studies assumed the existence of a network to optimize routing-on. In order to apply such a model in different environments, it is necessary to investigate what is a good representation of the environment. In this section, three methods for building the network that supports optimization are presented, the result of strategic optimization is compared for different representations of the environment and some key characteristics are identified.

sections.heading: A. Metrics description
sections.text: In his study of the one-dimensional problem, Ruckle identified the uniform distribution of paths along a line as the optimal strategy. This strategy corresponds to maximizing entropy of the probability distribution. On the basis of this idea, the probability of crossing along the median between departure and arrival is calculated. Entropy is used as the first measurement, it is high for deceptive routes and near zero for non-deceptive ones. The idea that the optimal strategy is evenly distributed over the environment led to the creation of another measurement, the scattering of the route, which measures the proportion of the area covered by the route as a fraction of the total surface of the environment. For each ambush area, the probability of entering this area can be calculated as the sum of the inflowing currents. If the area is reached with the probability p > pmin, the losses of this area in the scattering are calculated.

sections.heading: A. General framework description
sections.text: The environment is analysed for three different purposes: the first is to complete the existing road network with an off-road network to cover both structured and unstructured parts of the environment; the second is to identify relevant geographical areas for ambushes; the third is to calculate the local map of results; at each location, a correlation is established between the possible outcome of an ambush and the strategic characteristics of the local environment around that ambush. To achieve these objectives, data of various nature are used; altitude data on the environment is collected through data from the Shuttle Radar Topography Mission, which is publicly available [1]; and SRTM data is divided into two precision levels: SRTM1 (for the US and its territories and possessions) with data collected in an arc-second interval at latitude and longitude; and SRTM3 (for the entire world).

sections.heading: B. Risk factors
sections.text: In order to broaden the purely theoretical game theory problem and make it more realistic, interviews with former Army personnel were conducted, focusing on the identification of the factors with the greatest impact on the local outcome that could be included in the formulation of the optimization problem. Significant attention was therefore paid to identifying the various factors that affect the local outcomes. The relevant information can be divided into three different areas, which are presented in Figure 6. Firstly, the information related to the environment, whether described by topological or geological data, is crucial. This type of information includes data on altitudes, roads, waterways, as well as vegetation and terrain type and quality. Secondly, the strategic information, such as the resources of RED and BLUE (position, quantity, type) and previous encroachments, must be taken into account. Thirdly, the human factors correspond to other intelligent agents in the geographical region of interest that do not participate in the game.

sections.heading: VI. FUTURE WORK
sections.text: From a theoretical point of view, several aspects could be explored further: the convergence observed for the routes of all methods indicates the existence of a boundary distribution.Instead of the dense discretization developed in this essay, the authors would like to propose a continuous model of the present game, which would make it possible to identify the boundary distribution at once and possibly draw a parallel between the different paths between routes and homotopy classes.A number of applications have been envisaged. Currently, the only factor influencing the local outcome is the maximum speed at a particular location.The accuracy of the model could be improved by taking more risk factors into detail.The purpose of this framework is to provide a practical tool for route forecasting. However, the merging of structured and unstructured environments still requires manual coordination. This merging process will be automated more thoroughly in the forthcoming work. Finally, it may be interesting to increase the accuracy of environmental descriptions by one or two orders of magnitude.

sections.heading: VII. CONCLUSION
sections.text: This research defines the reach of the enemy as an important parameter of environmental representation, and the local result becomes more important because of its geographical importance; the possible losses to the system in a particular area in the event of an ambush are calculated by identifying the various factors influencing this result, which are related to the environment and the resources of the agents; by comparing different methods of network construction and different linear optimization algorithms, efficient techniques have been identified to develop strategies for avoiding ambush in unstructured environments; the results highlight the presence of sufficient network density to represent these environments; the correlation between the reach of the ambush and the optimal outcome of the game is illustrated; and a "representative distribution" is produced; and a comprehensive framework is elaborated.
